channel.name: What's the right way of using the MINA docker images?

messages.content:
For example this:

`sudo docker run -it minaprotocol/mina-archive:1.3.1.2-25388a0-focal`

returns:

```Usage: /usr/bin/dumb-init [option] program [args]
Try /usr/bin/dumb-init --help for full usage.```

and:

`sudo docker run -it minaprotocol/mina-archive:1.3.1.2-25388a0-focal mina version`

returns:

`[dumb-init] mina: No such file or directory`

These are the archive node images. For the Mina daemon see this https://docs.minaprotocol.com/node-operators/connecting-to-the-network#docker.  This link is for mainnet, so zkApps are not available there yet, and you would need to connect to the Berkeley network depending on what you are trying to do.
I'm trying to run an archive node for berkeley so I'm able to use fetch_events for all my actions. Tried docker since I'm on Ubuntu 22.04 and the normal installation process isn't working for my OS

Docs for archive node is here https://docs.minaprotocol.com/node-operators/archive-node. You need to run the Mina daemon and then it's a secondary process. These are current images for Berkeley:
`minaprotocol/mina-daemon:1.3.2beta2-release-2.0.0-05c2f73-focal-berkeley`
`minaprotocol/mina-archive:1.3.2beta2-release-2.0.0-05c2f73-focal`
fetchEvents isn't supported yet for a remote blockchain though (with or without the archive node), so are you planning on implementing this support yourself?
yes, some of my contract methods require to reduce actions, so i need a way to enable users executing these contract methods in the easiest way possible

Right, you'd need a few bits to get this to work currently, not least as there is no current interface to the archive node to get this data. 
As an aside, I was playing around with this in testing a while back and exposed historical sequence events via https://berkeley.graphql.minaexplorer.com/ - it's a little hacky, mainly as it's so deeply nested in GraphQL. I might eventually expose it as a separate collection as I have done for events for easier querying.

I see. I'll need to look into it more in depth then

Should I be going for running an archive node for this tho? Or I should use something else in the MIna toolset?

I think remote actions are supposed to be supported soon. So if you are not in an urgent need, or don't feel like trying to implement this on your own, your best bet might be to develop using the local blockchain where they are supported, so it's ready to go when they are. If you want to roll your own solution in the interim then yes either an archive node, or an archive service you can integrate with.
Oh, cool, I'm not in a rush, and always prefer using standard solutions so I'll wait, thanks 🙌
Just to confirm, but then at the moment actions and Reduce aren't available in any straightforward way for berkeley, even if you run your own node, right?
And even if I archive the events and manage to retrieve them, that won't work either, since you still couldn't execute the contract method that has a reduce in it
Right as no way to get pending actions from a remote blockchain currently in snarkyJS
Not entirely sure what you mean here but if you have the pending actions you could execute the reducer step - the part that is missing is getting the pending actions.

Oh, ok. Assuming I get the pending actions, then I could just feed them to my contract method as an argument of type actionType[][], and then pass it to reduce as an argument too, or something like that I guess
Cool, thanks again for your responses 🧐

how did you resolve this? i pulled the docker image but when i run i get error below , curious what command you ran to set the mina archive on docker : /usr/bin/dumb-init [option] program [args]
Try /usr/bin/dumb-init --help for full usage.

Hi, sorry, I didn't get to the point of successfully running the archive node, since remote actions were coming natively (not sure if this got implemented, I haven't revisited this), but since the archive node requires running the daemon and then the archive node as a secondary process, I would start by running the daemon container 🙂
